Award.AwardTitle: Identifying and Characterizing the Processes Controlling Iron Speciation and Residence Time at the Atmosphere-Ocean Interface
Award.AbstractNarration:
The funding provided here will be used to support participation in a scientific workshop on the topic of what happens to iron deposited from the atmosphere to the surface of the ocean. Iron is required for the growth of phytoplankton. The availability of iron can limit the growth of phytoplankton and thus the overall productivity of the marine ecosystem. Workshop participants with expertise in atmospheric chemistry, organic geochemistry, photochemistry, chemical oceanography, dust/aerosol geochemistry, and various aspects of atmospheric, ocean, and Earth system modeling will be brought together to discuss the complicated problem of iron chemistry at the atmosphere-ocean interface, and its effects. At least one-third of workshop invitees will be early-career scientists. The primary product of the workshop will be a white paper outlining the state of knowledge and prioritizing future research directions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is well recognized that the atmospheric deposition of iron (Fe) affects ocean productivity, atmospheric CO2 uptake, ecosystem diversity, and overall climate. Over the past decade, there have been great advances in the measurement and modeling of chemical composition, forms, redox speciation, and phases of aerosol Fe. The new instruments allow characterization of Fe content in atmospheric particles, micro to nanometer in size, and speciation of different oxidation forms of Fe down to tens of picograms (10-12 kg) in concentration. Oceanic models now routinely treat Fe cycling with external sources and sinks, dissolved, colloidal, particulate, inorganic, and organic ligand-complexed forms of Fe, as well as Fe in detritus and phytoplankton. Atmospheric models consider natural and anthropogenic sources of Fe, mobilization of Fe in mineral aerosols due to the dissolution of Fe-oxides and Fe-substituted aluminosilicates through proton-promoted, organic ligand-promoted, and photo-reductive mechanisms. Despite such progress, neither atmospheric nor ocean biogeochemistry models consider the processes that influence the physicochemical state of Fe at the atmosphere?ocean interface: the boundary that is crucially important for the bioavailability of this essential trace element. The lack of characterization of the processes controlling Fe speciation and residence time at the atmosphere-ocean interface is largely due to the: i) short lifetime and the myriad of physical, (photo)chemical and biological processes affecting in situ measurements of trace amounts of Fe, ii) absence of the unified nomenclature of the Fe-related terminology in atmospheric and oceanic science communities; and iii) classical funding structures that often create obstacles for transdisciplinary collaboration.

This workshop report is an assessment on Fe speciation and residence time at the atmosphere-ocean interface and represents a consensus reached by the researchers from the oceanographic and atmospheric science communities with backgrounds in the laboratory and in situ measurements, modeling, and remote sensing. The report is intended to aid scientists working on Fe biogeochemistry as well as program managers at the relevant funding agencies.
